Summary: GC 8/1. Localised unstable windslab on N through E to S aspects above 850m, elsewhere generally stable. Low Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Soft snow at most altitudes, localised knee deep in places.  Good visibility. Winds approx 10 - 20 mph feeling very cold.
Comment: Greater amounts of snow, up to 5cm, are possible if the snow showers overnight are more persistent. If this proves to be the case adjust the hazard upwards. Cornices will continue to form.
WeatherInfluences: Light snow showers overnight with strong Westerly winds easing. During the day it\'s expected to be dry. The freezing level will remain around 200 metres throughout.
SnowStability: There will be a covering of soft, generally stable snow on most aspects above 400 metres. Unstable windslab will continue to form in wind sheltered locations mainly on North-East to South-East aspects above 850 metres. These accumulations will be localised, mainly in steeper locations, gullies, gully tops and coire rims. North and South aspects may also be affected due to cross-loading. Areas exposed to the wind will become scoured. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A mainly dry and bright day with snow flurries down to around 300 metres. The winds were fresh to strong from a North-Westerly direction.
ObservedSnowStability: There is a cover of soft generally stable snow on most aspects above 400 metres. Fresh deposits of unstable windslab have formed in wind sheltered locations mainly on North-East to South-East aspects above 850 metres. These accumulations are localised, mainly in steeper locations, gullies, gully tops and coire rims. North and South aspects are also affected through cross-loading. Areas exposed to the wind are becoming scoured.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: CM for 8/1. Localised windslab on steep E, SE and S aspects above 950m. Generally stable elsewhere. Low hazard
Comment: Only light snow showers are expected overnight
WeatherInfluences: Snow showers will continue overnight before clearing during Wednesday. North-West winds will become light.
SnowStability: Localised areas of windslab will be present, mainly at the tops of steep East, South-East and South aspects above 950m, although distribution will be limited. Elsewhere, fresh snow will overlie bare ground and be generally stable. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: There have been some light snow showers during the period with moderate to strong North-Westerly winds over the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: A covering of fresh snow exists on many aspects above 300m but this is mostly superficial and is lying over bare ground. Some deeper accumulations of windslab are present, mainly at the tops of steep South-East and South aspects above 950m but accumulations tend to be localised in nature. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: TO 08/01 Avalanches likely E to S aspects above 700m, cross loading NE and SW aspects. Localised below 700m. Considerable Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Soft snow at all altitudes - very hard going on foot. Thigh deep in drifts at 400m! Blizzard and whiteout conditions presenting challenging and serious conditions. Winds 20 -30 mph progress difficult at times with stronger gusts.
Comment: Snowed all day down to sea level; Very challenging making any progress in deep soft snow. A further 20cm snow is expected over the next 24 hours adding to the already unstable snowpack.
WeatherInfluences: Very strong North-Westerly winds easing from early morning. Frequent snow showers are expected throughout the forecast period, bringing as much as a further 20cm of new snow. The freezing level is expected to be around 300 meters.
SnowStability: Unstable windslab will continue to develop in both depth and distribution overlaying multiple weaknesses within the snowpack. East to South aspects mainly affected above 700 meters. Here, avalanches are likely. North-East and South-West aspects will also be affected due to cross loading. Below 700 meters unstable windslab will further develop on East to South aspects in wind-sheltered locations such as depressions and gully lines. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Strong North-Westerly winds. Almost continuous snow showers down to sea level. The freezing level was around 300 meters.
ObservedSnowStability: Unstable windslab continued to build on North-East,  through South-East to South-West aspects above 700 meters.  This overlay multiple weaknesses within the snowpack beneath.  Below 700 meters on East to South aspects unstable windslab was also present affecting wind-sheltered locations such as depressions and gully lines. On other aspects the snow cover remains unconsolidated and generally stable. The avalanche hazard is Considerable.

Summary: SC for 8.1.25: Areas of unstable windslab will be present in lee locations on E,SE,S and SW aspects above 800m. Moderate hazard.
SnowDistribution: Wind scoured and bare on some aspects with deep drifts in lee locations.  Occasional visibility throughout the day above 600 metres. Winds approx 40 - 50 mph making progress very difficult and strenuous.
Comment: Drifts are becoming much deeper on tracks and footpaths making mountain travel hard work.
WeatherInfluences: Remaining cold but very little new snow is expected. The North-Westerly winds will remain very strong overnight but ease during the day to become a strong breeze.
SnowStability: Redistribution of existing snow will continue the development of unstable windslab in wind sheltered locations on East through South to South-West aspects above 800 metres. Deep drifts will also be encountered in any lee locations on other aspects and at lower elevations. Fragile cornices will continue to form. Areas exposed to the wind will remain scoured and stable.  The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Light snowfall was accompanied by persistent drifting throughout the day. The cloud occasionally lifted from the hills at times.
ObservedSnowStability: Areas of unstable windslab have continued to build in wind sheltered locations mostly on East through South to South-West aspects above 800 metres. These areas are not widespread but are only moderately well bonded where encountered. Elsewhere, very deep drifts have developed in lee locations. Exposed areas remain scoured and icy. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: LO for 8.1 Unstable windslab mainly on NE-E-S aspcts abve 900m. Deposits not expected to be extensive nor gain signif depth. Haz Low
SnowDistribution: Ground frozen at all levels, with icy paths and icy patches on hillsides. Cloudy on the tops, brighter during the afternoon.  Winds 10-20 mph.
Comment: Only light snow showers are expected overnight, but if they become more persistent up to 5cm of snow is possible. If this proves to be the case adjust the hazard upwards accordingly.
WeatherInfluences: Winds are expected to be strong mainly West-North-Westerly overnight, easing during the morning to light to moderate mainly Westerly. Light snow showers at most levels are expected overnight, then a dry day. It will remain cold, with the freezing level around 200 or 300 metres.
SnowStability: New unstable windslab will be deposited in wind sheltered areas, mainly on North-East through East to South aspects above 900 metres. Accumulations are not expected to be extensive nor gain significant depth. Steep coire rims, tops of gullies and flanks of ridges will be most affected. There will be a covering of soft snow on all aspects above around 300 metres.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: There were some light snow showers at most levels. Winds were light, occasionally moderate, mainly North-Westerly. It was freezing at most levels.
ObservedSnowStability: There is a thin covering of new snow on all aspects above around 300 metres. Localised fresh unstable windslab has been deposited in wind sheltered areas, mainly on North-East through East to South aspects above 950 metres. Accumulations gaining depth are limited in extent, mainly on steep ground at the tops of gullies, around coire rims and along ridge flanks. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: NC for 8.1 Unstable windslab all aspects above 800m greatest instability E,SE,S,SW avalanches likely. Avalanche Hazard Considerable.
SnowDistribution: Deep snow at all altitudes, becoming quite hard going. Whiteout conditions. Winds 20-30 mph augmenting the poor visibility with drifting snow.
Comment: Poor visibility may create challenges in the identification of unstable windslab in the field.
WeatherInfluences: Further snowfall is expected overnight from glen level upwards, followed by a dry day. Winds will be mostly West-North-Westerly, very strong overnight becoming fresh to strong during the day. The freezing level will be around 300 metres for the duration of the period.
SnowStability: Unstable windslab will be present on most aspects above 800 metres becoming more widespread on steep East through South-East to South-West aspects, where avalanches are likely. Coire headwalls, gullies and convexities will be the most affected. Fragile cornices will continue to develop. Below 800m localised windslab will develop on steep banks and in stream lines. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Snowfall throughout the period, with some occasional clearer spells at glen level. Winds,Westerly to North-Westerly, very strong to gale force. The freezing level was around 400 metres at midday.
ObservedSnowStability: Unstable windslab continues to build on all aspects above 800 metres, with more widespread and deeper accumulations on steep East through South-East to South-West aspects. Coire headwalls, gullies and convexities are most affected. Here also fragile cornices continue to develop. Below 800 metres localised soft windslab is also present in steep banks and wind sheltered hollows. The avalanche hazard is Considerable.
